results.contentPreview: Check if you qualify‚Ä¶ register with the Charity Commission (CCNI)‚Ä¶
results.content:
Set up a Charity ‚Äì Step by Step (UK / NI) [Stub]

Source: GOV.UK (https://www.gov.uk/set-up-a-charity)

1. Check if you qualify as a charity:
   - Must have charitable purposes only.
   - Must benefit the public.

2. Choose trustees:
   - Minimum of 3 trustees recommended.
   - Cannot be disqualified individuals.

3. Create a governing document:
   - E.g. constitution, trust deed, or articles of association.

4. Name your charity:
   - Must not mislead or be too similar to existing names.

5. Register with the Charity Commission:
   - In Northern Ireland: Charity Commission for NI (CCNI).
   - Provide trustee details, governing document, income details.

6. Get a charity number (once approved).

results.title: Trustee Duties ‚Äì Quick Reference
results.contentPreview: Act in best interests, manage resources, serious incident reporting‚Ä¶
results.content:
Trustee Duties ‚Äì Quick Reference (UK / NI) [Stub]

Source: Charity Commission NI guidance

Trustees must:
- Act only in the charity‚Äôs best interests.
- Manage charity resources responsibly (budgets, controls).
- Comply with charity law and reporting requirements.
- Prepare and file annual accounts and reports.
- Declare and manage conflicts of interest.
- Ensure safeguarding and data protection policies are followed.
- Report serious incidents promptly to CCNI.

Failure to comply may lead to investigation or disqualification.

results.title: Annual Reporting & Accounts
results.contentPreview: Annual reporting due within 10 months; thresholds for scrutiny‚Ä¶
results.content:
Annual Reporting & Accounts ‚Äì Charity Commission NI [Stub]

1. All registered charities must report annually.
2. Requirements depend on income:
   - Under ¬£250,000: Receipts & Payments accounts may be used.
   - Over ¬£250,000: Accruals accounts required.
   - Over ¬£500,000: Accounts must be audited.
3. Trustees‚Äô Annual Report must be submitted alongside accounts.
4. Deadline: Within 10 months of financial year end.
5. Reports are published on the public register for transparency.

results.title: Fundraising & Safeguarding ‚Äì Charity Essentials
results.contentPreview: Legal, open, honest fundraising; safeguarding policy & training‚Ä¶
results.content:
Fundraising & Safeguarding ‚Äì Charity Essentials [Stub]

Fundraising:
- Must be legal, open, honest, and respectful.
- Keep accurate records of fundraising income and expenditure.
- Avoid misleading or pressuring donors.
- Follow the Code of Fundraising Practice.

Safeguarding:
- Trustees are accountable for safeguarding policies.
- Protect children and vulnerable adults from harm.
- Ensure regular training for staff and volunteers.
- Review safeguarding policies annually.

results.title: Introduction ‚Äî Regulation of Charities in NI
results.contentPreview: Framework from Charities Act (NI) 2008; 2015 regulations; 2022 Act‚Ä¶
results.content:
Introduction ‚Äî Regulation of Charities in Northern Ireland

Under laws led by the Department for Communities, charities in Northern Ireland are regulated primarily via:
- The Charities (Accounts and Reports) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2015, which took effect 1 January 2016, requiring registered charities to file annual accounts and reports.
- The Charities Act (Northern Ireland) 2008 (amended later) as the foundation of the legal framework.
- Successive Commencement Orders and amendment Acts to bring sections into force over time.
- The Charities Act (Northern Ireland) 2022, which among other things addresses decisions made by the Commission before May 2019.

Charities must comply with financial reporting, public benefit requirements, oversight, and may be subject to investigation or enforcement by the Charity Commission for Northern Ireland.

results.title: Charities (Accounts & Reports) Regulations (NI) 2015
results.contentPreview: Preparation & submission of accounts; financial years from 2016‚Ä¶
results.content:
Charities (Accounts & Reports) Regulations (NI) 2015 ‚Äî Summary (Stub)

- These regulations require registered charities in Northern Ireland to prepare and submit accounts and annual reports.
- They cover group accounts, scrutiny, consistency in accounting treatment.
- They apply to financial years beginning on or after 1 January 2016.
- The regulations were introduced alongside the Charities Act (2008) substitution orders to raise thresholds (e.g. accruals vs receipts & payments) from ¬£100,000 to ¬£250,000.
- Charities must file their reports and accounts with the Charity Commission for Northern Ireland as part of compliance.

results.title: Charity (Failed Appeals & Disclaimers) Regulations (NI) 2013
results.contentPreview: What to do when fundraising appeals fail; donor disclaimers‚Ä¶
results.content:
Charity (Failed Appeals & Disclaimers) Regulations (NI) 2013 ‚Äî Summary (Stub)

- These regulations allow guidance on what to do when a fundraising appeal does not meet its target.
- If an appeal fails, trustees may return donations to original donors, or apply to the Commission for a ‚Äúscheme‚Äù to amend the appeal‚Äôs purpose.
- The regulations include a specimen donor disclaimer form to allow donors to disclaim property rights.
- They took effect 1 July 2013.

results.title: Independent Review of Charity Regulation (2021)
results.content:
Independent Review of Charity Regulation in Northern Ireland ‚Äî Overview (Stub)

- Commissioned by the Minister for Communities, the Review began 25 January 2021.
- Its goal: examine how well the Charities Act (NI) 2008, and the roles of the Commission and Department, strike a balance between supporting charities and dealing with misconduct.
- The Panel made 93 recommendations for improving regulatory delivery and legal framework.
- At time of stub: The Department is considering responses and planning an Action Plan.

results.title: Public Benefit & Registration in NI
results.contentPreview: Registration when called forward; public benefit statement‚Ä¶
results.content:
Public Benefit Requirement & Charity Registration in NI ‚Äî Stub

- The public benefit test in NI was delayed under the Charities Act (Northern Ireland) 2008 due to technical difficulties; it was resolved via the 2013 Act.
- Every charity in Northern Ireland must register when ‚Äúcalled forward‚Äù by the Commission; registration is not automatic.
- To register: must show exclusively charitable purposes, governed by NI law, be independent, and submit supporting documents (governing document, trustee details, income, etc.).
- Registration support includes trustee declarations, public benefit toolkits, and checklists provided by the Commission.
- Some decisions by the Commission before 2019 were later made lawful by the 2022 Act.

results.title: CTO Insights ‚Äî Charity IT Infrastructure Costs
results.contentPreview: Executive view of recurring and capital IT costs; cloud, security, M365, backups, DR, FinOps‚Ä¶
results.content:
CTO Insights ‚Äî Charity IT Infrastructure Costs [Restricted: CTO]

Purpose
- Provide an executive view of recurring and capital IT costs for a medium UK/NI charity.
- Support budgeting, risk reduction, and service reliability decisions.

Cost Categories (Opex unless noted)
1) Cloud hosting (IaaS/PaaS/SaaS)
   - Prod/non-prod compute, storage, bandwidth, managed DBs, backups, CDN.
   - Cost drivers: traffic peaks, data egress, reserved instances, storage tiers.
   - Optimisation: rightsizing, autoscaling, reserved/savings plans, lifecycle policies.

2) Identity & Security
   - M365/Azure AD licensing, MFA, SSO, conditional access.
   - Security tooling: EDR, email security, vulnerability mgmt, SIEM/SOAR.
   - Compliance: backups, retention, encryption key mgmt, audit logging.

3) End‚ÄëUser Computing
   - Device procurement (Capex), warranty, MDM/MAM, OS licensing, VDI/DaaS if used.
   - Accessibility tooling; assistive tech licenses.

4) Collaboration & Data
   - SharePoint/OneDrive, Teams, Exchange Online, Power BI/analytics licensing.
   - Data platform: ETL/ELT, warehouse/lake storage, data retention costs.

5) Line‚Äëof‚ÄëBusiness & Fundraising Systems
   - CRM/donor mgmt (e.g., Dynamics/Salesforce), Gift Aid processing add‚Äëons.
   - Payment gateway fees, PCI DSS impacts, consent mgmt (UK GDPR).

6) Business Continuity
   - Backups (3‚Äë2‚Äë1), DR regions, RPO/RTO testing, incident response retainers.

7) External Services
   - MSP/outsourcing, support SLAs, project/professional services, training.

Budgeting & KPIs
- Run‚Äërate per month; unit costs (per user, per donor, per transaction).
- Availability SLOs (e.g., 99.9%), MTTR, backup success %, patch compliance.
- Cloud cost anomaly alerts; forecast vs actual; cost per ¬£1 of donation processed.

Recommendations (12‚Äëmonth horizon)
- Adopt tagging & FinOps discipline; quarterly rightsizing.
- Migrate static content to cold storage; enable CDN & caching.
- Consolidate security tools; negotiate multi‚Äëyear licensing discounts.
- Implement zero‚Äëtrust baseline; enforce least privilege & conditional access.
- Document DR plan; quarterly restore tests; define Recovery Playbooks.

Notes
- This document is **restricted** to CTO/CIO and authorised finance leads.
- Distribution outside the exec group requires approval.
